docs.snippet: A rivalry between Mr. Espaillat and Guillermo Linares could split Tuesday’s congressional primary vote among their immigrant countrymen....
docs.lead_paragraph: A rivalry between Mr. Espaillat and Guillermo Linares could split Tuesday’s congressional primary vote among their immigrant countrymen.
docs.abstract: New York State Sen Adriano Espaillat faces off against Guillermo Linares in race for Democratic nomination for Upper Manhattan district represented by Rep Charles B Rangel, who is retiring; both men are Dominican-born, and would be first to be elected to House of Representatives if one of them wins Rangel's seat; some voters and activists believe men could split Dominican vote and hand nomination to another candidate.

headline.main: Espaillat Emerges From Rangel’s Shadow, but Finds Another Familiar Foe
headline.print_headline: Espaillat Finds Familiar Foe in House Race for Rangel Seat

docs.snippet: Legal or not, an episode involving the parks department’s purchase of mint-scented garbage bags shows the collapse of the city’s carefully constructed defenses against “pay to play” government....
docs.lead_paragraph: Legal or not, an episode involving the parks department’s purchase of mint-scented garbage bags shows the collapse of the city’s carefully constructed defenses against “pay to play” government.
docs.abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column examines investigation by FBI into relationship between Mayor Bill de Blasio's office and Joseph Dussich, owner of JAD Corporation of America, Queens-based trash bag company; FBI believes Dussich contributed money to Campaign for One New York, political advocacy group run by mayor's allies, and was subsequently given contract with parks department for sale of rat-proof garbage bags.

headline.main: Why Trash Bags That Repel Rats Have the F.B.I. Sniffing Around in New York
headline.print_headline: Why Trash Bags That Repel Rats Have the F.B.I. Sniffing Around

docs.snippet: The deadlocked Supreme Court’s ruling against President Obama left many immigrants fearful of deportation, but others said they would continue their fight....
docs.lead_paragraph: The deadlocked Supreme Court’s ruling against President Obama left many immigrants fearful of deportation, but others said they would continue their fight.
docs.abstract: Many families of undocumented immigrants fear they will be deported after Supreme Court announced it is divided in case concerning Pres Obama's executive actions intended to shield illegal immigrants from deportation.

headline.main: Tears Flow and Spirits Sag, but Some Immigrants Look to November With Determination
headline.print_headline: As Tears Flow and Spirits Sag, Some Look to November With Determination
